text:
Hi all! Curious to get some perspective on how different teams measure the success of their content program. 

Do you have a North Star for your team (leads, new customers, revenue) and if so how do you measure it?

In past I’ve had exec leadership teams that care a ton about traffic, while others that just want to get straight to revenue, based on the maturity of the business at the time. 

Curious to hear where others are focused, and ways you’ve found to communicate success or leading indicators, when getting straight to revenue is expected, but only one part of the whole content strategy!

elements.text:
Hi all! Curious to get some perspective on how different teams measure the success of their content program. 

Do you have a North Star for your team (leads, new customers, revenue) and if so how do you measure it?

In past I’ve had exec leadership teams that care a ton about traffic, while others that just want to get straight to revenue, based on the maturity of the business at the time. 

Curious to hear where others are focused, and ways you’ve found to communicate success or leading indicators, when getting straight to revenue is expected, but only one part of the whole content strategy!

text:
With all of my customers, it's both.

I'm educated them to the intangible benefits of content as well as the tangible.

In reality this looks like:
1. Are we growing and getting better? (Traffic + authority + time on page)
2. Is content marketing profitable (lead/demo/sign up/install requests being attributable to content)
3. Are we attracting the right customers? (Average customer value + # of types of customer)
This means at any one time I have multiple reasons for creating content. A lot of people will do it differently, and with more resource you can have different departments for each area or even KPI.

As a solo marketer embedded as a content strategist with most of my clients, ticking all the boxes is a challenge. But it's nowhere near as much of a challenge as it was before everybody was bought-in and knew why we did what we did.

Are we attracting the right customers? (Average customer value + # of types of customer)

text: as a user I always appreciating see both published date and last modified date, and I would just add that your source code should list both (and might already) in an easy to access way for crawlers, eg. <https://schema.org/datePublished> and <https://schema.org/dateModified>

attachments.title: datePublished - Schema.org Property
attachments.text: <http://Schema.org|Schema.org> Property: datePublished - Date of first broadcast/publication.

attachments.title: dateModified - Schema.org Property
attachments.text: <http://Schema.org|Schema.org> Property: dateModified - The date on which the CreativeWork was most recently modified or when the item's entry was modified within a DataFeed.

text:
Newsletter question:

I'm building out an email newsletter strategy (first for this startup brand). I want to start off with a note from the CEO/co-founder. The challenge: there are technically four co-founders (in charge of different areas of the business, engineering, sales, etc.).

I'd rather have the CEO be the "face" of the newsletter for consistency and brand building. He's also done the most with thought leadership. But I have others saying we should switch between each co-founder for equal promotion/political reasons.

What are your thoughts?

elements.text:
Newsletter question:

I'm building out an email newsletter strategy (first for this startup brand). I want to start off with a note from the CEO/co-founder. The challenge: there are technically four co-founders (in charge of different areas of the business, engineering, sales, etc.).

I'd rather have the CEO be the "face" of the newsletter for consistency and brand building. He's also done the most with thought leadership. But I have others saying we should switch between each co-founder for equal promotion/political reasons.

What are your thoughts?

text: I can always include a link to a thought leadership piece from one of the others so they're represented.

elements.text: I can always include a link to a thought leadership piece from one of the others so they're represented.

text: <@U022P09NXS7> You can still have the CEO be the 'face' of the campaign while promoting guest blasts from the other co-founders. It's great when a B2B audience doesn't just hear from the most seen spokesperson but also the leaders tasked with the actual product build and other parts of storytelling. This gives prospects/customers more opportunities to learn more about the brand, from different personas and that's always a bit more interesting versus from the same 'voice', all the time.

elements.text: You can still have the CEO be the 'face' of the campaign while promoting guest blasts from the other co-founders. It's great when a B2B audience doesn't just hear from the most seen spokesperson but also the leaders tasked with the actual product build and other parts of storytelling. This gives prospects/customers more opportunities to learn more about the brand, from different personas and that's always a bit more interesting versus from the same 'voice', all the time.

text: To play devil's advocate to <@U01V7P0HZ51>'s good point above...I like to have ONE voice of the company in a newsletter. Your email audience is bombarded with email, and you're more likely to build a strong brand over time if you have ONE clear name/face/headshot/voice that shows up every time. Years ago, Hubspot set the best practice that emails should be from a PERSON, not a brand, and I like it when emails are from the same person every time. I know that as an email recipient, I'm often wondering "Who's Mary?" (or whoever) when I get emails from a ton of different people at a brand I don't know well.

elements.text: To play devil's advocate to

's good point above...I like to have ONE voice of the company in a newsletter. Your email audience is bombarded with email, and you're more likely to build a strong brand over time if you have ONE clear name/face/headshot/voice that shows up every time. Years ago, Hubspot set the best practice that emails should be from a PERSON, not a brand, and I like it when emails are from the same person every time. I know that as an email recipient, I'm often wondering "Who's Mary?" (or whoever) when I get emails from a ton of different people at a brand I don't know well.

text: Fair point <@U01DEA6F7CH>. Our agency predominantly works with EmergingTech/AdvancedTech brands (e.g. AI/ML tools, industrial manufacturers etc) and we actually found newsletters coming from CSOs/CTOs in addition to the CEO had increased resonance/engagement so I'd chalk a significant part of this decision up to what is currently known about your audience affinities and behavior.

elements.text: Fair point

. Our agency predominantly works with EmergingTech/AdvancedTech brands (e.g. AI/ML tools, industrial manufacturers etc) and we actually found newsletters coming from CSOs/CTOs in addition to the CEO had increased resonance/engagement so I'd chalk a significant part of this decision up to what is currently known about your audience affinities and behavior.

text:
We have a few buckets for things like this:

-A person who most emails come "from" - this is who our webinar invites, content pieces, more generic email content comes from
-Our CEO - this is for more important announcements. It's frequent enough people recognize his name, but infrequent enough that it conveys a more significant level of importance
-Subject matter experts for other messages - we use our CTO (who is also a co-founder) to announce new products and major features, or our Chief Customer Officer when we want to send messages related to his expertise. These are less common, and we sometimes see better open rates because folks don't recognize the name and therefore don't see them as a blast email

-A person who most emails come "from" - this is who our webinar invites, content pieces, more generic email content comes from
-Our CEO - this is for more important announcements. It's frequent enough people recognize his name, but infrequent enough that it conveys a more significant level of importance
-Subject matter experts for other messages - we use our CTO (who is also a co-founder) to announce new products and major features, or our Chief Customer Officer when we want to send messages related to his expertise. These are less common, and we sometimes see better open rates because folks don't recognize the name and therefore don't see them as a blast email

text:
To combine <@U01V7P0HZ51> and <@U01DEA6F7CH>'s concepts:

CEO is the "from" and the "voice."

When the topic is aligned with the other CXOs or CoFounders, the CEO introduces them inside the email and lets their voice ring through. CEO opens and closes the email. Include headshot of the "guest" but always make a "guest sandwich" out of the CEO's voice.

elements.text: To combine
and

's concepts:

CEO is the "from" and the "voice."

When the topic is aligned with the other CXOs or CoFounders, the CEO introduces them inside the email and lets their voice ring through. CEO opens and closes the email. Include headshot of the "guest" but always make a "guest sandwich" out of the CEO's voice.

text: Thanks for this thoughtful response, <@UJJFDTN8G>! Agree it’s less about ticking all the boxes, and focusing in on the right ones based on where the business is at and needs to grow.

text: Looking to present our overall content strategy to the rest of the marketing team in the next few weeks. Have done the leg work in terms of research / buyer persona / and suggested content themes, but struggling with the best way to present all of this info. Notion pages? Deck? Combination of both? Anyone have a good template / examples on how to really hone in on our what we’re doing and why?

text: Ronnie has great questions. Those were definitely considerations I had when putting together my content strategy to present. Ultimately I made a deck and linked out to research and data in sheets to back up some of the why. And then made a second version that was more of an executive summary/less in the weeds.

text:
Similar to what <@U020HB0P648> said, those are going to be two different presentations. Your VP of Marketing might be interested in the finer details like research, personas, and themes. But when it comes down to brass tacks, they're more than likely going to want to know how it helps them achieve their goals. The finer details can be in the appendix if they happen to be curious.

In regards to the format, I'm going to strongly suggest a slide deck and consume everything Nancy Duarte says about slide decks and presentations.

In regards to the format, I'm going to strongly suggest a slide deck and consume everything Nancy Duarte says about slide decks and presentations.
